docs.lead_paragraph: One couple’s 388-day ordeal — and their unlikely saviors.
docs.abstract: Paul and Rachel Chandler were held captive for 388 days by Somali pirates in one of the longest periods of captivity for the thousands of people who have been held for ransom by the pirates who operate in the Gulf of Aden; their experience offers a unique insight into the lives of hostages and the society in which the pirates live and work.
docs.snippet: One couple’s 388-day ordeal — and their unlikely saviors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Metropolitan's cover article last week, by John Leland, told of a 58-year-old, uninsured illegal immigrant from Hong Kong who spent 19 months in New York Downtown Hospital after suffering a stroke, because his family would not take him. Outrage over his long stay -- and its $1.4 million cost, largely unpaid -- erupted in more than 230 reader comments on NYTimes.com; below is a sampling. Readers also wrote about Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, which criticized the New York Police Department's response to Occupy Wall Street and some earlier protests. I've worked in many hospitals in the region, and this is an astoundingly common problem. Each state has its own laws. Whereas in NYC, an undocumented, uninsured individual is able to get dialysis covered, this is not true in New Jersey, and one cannot get discharged without a dialysis center accepting them. I have seen young men sitting in hospital beds for months and even years, while social work figures out how to get them placed. It's heartbreaking to see these people trapped in the hospital.

headline.main: In Bed for 19 Months, At Hospital's Expense

docs.lead_paragraph: A United States task force’s recommendation against routine prostate-specific antigen testing for prostate cancer may lead to changes in insurance and practice.

docs.lead_paragraph: The good that Democratic health care reforms do for Americans is undeniable. It is heartening to see President Obama defend the policy with no apologies.

docs.lead_paragraph: American employers added 103,000 jobs in September, the Labor Department said Friday, indicating that the economy is at least not weakening. The jobless rate held steady at 9.1 percent.

headline.seo: Modest Growth in Jobs Tempers Recession Fears
headline.main: Adding Jobs, but Not Many, U.S. Economy Seems to Idle
headline.print_headline: Modest Growth In Jobs Tempers Recession Fears

docs.snippet: American employers added 103,000 jobs in September, the Labor Department said Friday, indicating that the economy is at least not weakening. The jobless rate held steady at 9.1 percent.

byline.contributor: Jennifer Steinhauer and Michael Shear contributed reporting from Washington.
